Award.AwardTitle: Measuring the Impact of Digital Repositories

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Digital data repositories have become increasingly important across research communities in recent years due to changing expectations around data from funders and scientists. Managers, funders, and users of digital data repositories are interested in assessing and communicating the impact of such repositories. A systematic approach and well-understood metrics, that may be quantitative or qualitative in nature, are needed to determine impact. Various stakeholders that include repository evaluators, repository managers, information studies scholars, and researchers and other data producers need to come together to develop relevant metrics to measure and document impact and outcomes. To this end, the College of Information Studies, University of Maryland, College Park proposes to facilitate a workshop that will gather these various stakeholders for open discussion around digital data repository impact and evaluation. The goal of this workshop is to identify the current metrics, tools, and practices that are effective, and the issues that will require additional research.

Improvements to metrics used for the evaluation of digital repository services and their impacts on research is a topic which is well-suited to the workshop format in this proposal. Conversations across stakeholder communities do not happen often enough, but they are vital to the sustainable development of digital data repositories. This workshop will bring together a diverse set of stakeholders around digital data repositories to discuss strategies and methods to better assess the impact of repository services. Impact assessments are key to understanding outcomes and necessary to refine and modify programs and infrastructures. The development of more robust repository metrics will influence and transform practices in these organizations, broadening access to research data. Additionally, a report will be publicly released following the workshop so the results will have increased visibility beyond the participants and their
institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In recent years digital repositories have become an increasingly vital part of the research and information infrastructure for scholars across disciplines. However, the diversity of the repository landscape has meant that understanding common practices and considering the impact of these organizations on the research process has remained difficult. To this end, the "Measuring the Impact of Digital Repositories" project sought to draw together related strands of research and practice around assessment, impact evaluation, and digital repository management in order to advance the field and spur new ideas. The goals of the project were to:

  • Identify current metrics, tools and methodologies for assessing and communicating the impact of digital repositories
  • Identify technical, social and financial obstacles
  • Synthesize the results into a set of best practices for both near and long term success, as well as a set of research topics designed to advance the creation and adoption of high quality evaluation criteria.

In service of these goals, the Investigators convened two workshops with related groups of stakeholders in the digital repository community. The first workshop took place in February/March 2017, and the second workshop took place in April 2019. Many of the attendees at the first workshop managed repositories, worked at funding agencies, or represented publishers with an interest in repositories and impact. The group at the second workshop drew from the practice community of folks working in libraries and archives who build and manage digital repositories, as well as researchers from the information field whose work addresses impact, metrics and evaluation.

Each workshop generated significant value for the community, engaging diverse sets of stakeholders that do not often speak directly to each other although their interests in the ongoing success of digital repository infrastructure development are closely aligned. One of the key conclusions of the conversation at the first workshop was that these conversations should happen more often to better align research and practice on digital repository evaluation, metrics, and impact assessment.

Draft reports were generated from each workshop summarizing the outcomes of the meetings and steps forward for this community. Among these were the need for more research to understand how different types of digital repositories measure impact and how they report on these to their audiences (e.g. funders, users, peer organizations). Once made public, these reports can become catalysts for more research on digital repositories and further galvanize this nascent community of practice.
